event.title: The Two Gentlemen of Verona by William Shakespeare
event.shortdesc: The Two Gentlemen of Verona by William Shakespeare

fulldesc.p: The Two Gentlemen of Verona by William ShakespeareÂ
A University Theatre Production
Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville UniversityÂ
Director Tony Elliot

TICKETS: Open Seating
$10.00 PublicÂ
$7.00 MU ID (at the door), Senior Citizens, and Students
$5.00 MU ID super saver advance sales only at the SMC
Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM at the Student Memorial Center or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com
SCHOOL DAY PERFORMANCES March 2-6. Contact Tony Elliot at 717-872-2335 or at tony.elliot@millersville.edu for more information.
Shakespeare knows how to make us laugh! Â

In this hilarious story of friendship, betrayal and lusty infatuation, two young men, Valentine and Proteus are learning about life and love as they make their way from Verona to Milan. Valentine's father is sending him to take a position in the Duke's court.Â Proteus accompanies him, reluctantly, not wanting to leave his beloved Julia. Meanwhile, Julia, and her maid Lucetta, disguise themselves as men and follow the boys to Milan.Â Add a dog named Crab and things get considerably more comical and complicated.Â
Once you know the story of Valentine and Proteus, you'll be wondering why you haven't met these "Two Gentlemenâ before.

p.strong: AUDITIONS: November 10 & 11, for both Spring 09 Shows, 7:00 PM to 10:00 PM, Dutcher Hall

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px
font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

div.p:
An ambivalent Cinderella? A blood-thirsty Little Red Ridinghood? A Prince Charming with a roving eye? A Witch-who raps? They're all among the cockeyed characters in James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim's fractured fairy tale. When a Baker and his Wife learn they've been cursed with childlessness by the Witch next door, they embark on a quest for the special objects required to break the spell, swindling, lying to and stealing from Cinderella, Little Red, Rapunzel and Jack (the one who climbed the beanstalk). Everyone's wish is granted at the end of Act One, but the consequences of their actions return to haunt them later, with disastrous results. What begins a lively irreverent fantasy in the style of "The Princess Brideâ becomes a moving lesson about community responsibility and the stories we tell our children.
PG 13Â RatingÂ

fulldesc.p: The American Place Theatre's Literature to Life® Arts Education Program, led by Artistic Director Wynn Handman and Executive Director David Kener. Literature to Life®, is a performance based literacy program, presents professionally staged verbatim adaptations of significant American literary works. This educational program gives students a new form of access to literature by bringing to life the world of books with performances that create an atmosphere of discovery and spark the imagination. Literature to Life encourages reading, writing, and critical thinking and provides a catalyst for learning and self-expression for over 100,000 students nationwide. The Theatre, having received over 30 Obies and 16 Audelcos, is critically acclaimed as a birthing place for artistic endeavors at the crossroad of literature and live performance for over 45 years.

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: The Kite Runner by Khaled Hosseini The beauty and agony of Afghanistan and the improbable friendship between two boys on the opposite ends of this society.Â

event.title: The Shape of Things by Neil LaBute
event.shortdesc: Presented by Millersville University Theatre

fulldesc.p: Rafters Theatre, Dutcher Hall, Millersville University
Guest Director Kevin Ditzler
TICKETS: Open Seating
$10.00 Public
$7.00 MU ID (at the door), Senior Citizens, and other Students
$5.00 MU ID super saver advance sales only at the SMC
Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM at the Student Memorial Center or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com
How far would you go for love? For art? What sacrifices would you make? What price would you be willing to pay? Such are the painful questions explored by Neil LaBute in, The Shape of Things.

After a chance meeting in a museum, Evelyn, a sexy, aggressive artist, and Adam, a shy, insecure student, become embroiled in an intense intimacy. Before long, it veers into the kind of dangerous, seductive territory that LaBute does best, as Adam, under Evelyn's steady influence, goes to unimaginable lengths to improve his appearance and character.
The Shape of Things challenges our most deeply entrenched ideas about art and love.
DUE TO SOME LANGUAGE AND SITUATIONS, THIS PLAY IS RECOMMENDED FOR MATURE AUDIENCES.

p.strong: AUDITIONS: November 10 & 11, for both Spring 09 Shows, 7:00 PM to 10:00 PM, Dutcher Hall

event.title: FOLKLORE URBANO
event.shortdesc: Pablo Mayor's 12 piece band takes the seductive Colombian rhythms and entwines them with jazz harmonies.
event.fulldesc:
Folklore Urbano
A Cultural Affairs Committee EventÂ
Saturday, April 18, 2009
7:00 PM
TICKETS
$10.00 General Admission
$7.00 MU ID, Senior Citizens
$5.00 MU IDÂ two per MU IDÂ
It's no exaggeration to say that Folklore Urbano has redefined modern Colombian music. Â This brilliant 12-piece ensemble harnesses the danceable swing of traditional Colombian folkloric rhythms while seducing the listener with the subtleties of jazz orchestration and harmony. The band's lineup cooks with two vocalists; a rhythm section comprised of some of New York City's finest exponents of traditional Colombian music; a stunning horn section of flute,trumpet, alto/soprano saxophone, baritone saxophone, and euphonium; as well as drum set, bass, and piano.
"-Folklore Urbano's 12 members perform material that is authentic and refreshing, due in no small part to Mayor's amazing way of synthesizing jazz with Colombian folkloric music, taking Latin music to anentirely new dimensionâ Â Vicky Sola, Latin Beat Magazine, Feb. 2006 issue.Â

event.title: Holocaust Lecture by Daniel Brown
event.shortdesc: RESISTING GENOCIDE: HISTORY, CULTURE AND THE ARTS IN THE HOLOCAUST AND BEYOND The Beautiful Beast: The Life and Crimes of SS-Aufseherin Irma Grese lecture by Daniel P. Brown

fulldesc.p: RESISTING GENOCIDE: HISTORY, CULTURE AND THE ARTS IN THE HOLOCAUST AND BEYOND
The Beautiful Beast: The Life and Crimes of SS-Aufseherin Irma Grese

Daniel P. Brown
Moorpark College, California
Dr. Daniel Brown is the author of The Camp Women: Female Auxiliaries Who Assisted the SS in Running the Nazi Concentration Camp System as well as the biographical study, The Beautiful Beast: The Life and Crimes of SS-Aufseherin Irma Grese.

Participating in the Discussion: Alice Tenenbaum - Holocaust Survivor, Auschwitz; Steven Rogers
Office of Special Investigations, U.S. Department of Justice

University Room, Gordinier Conference Center
Friday, April 3, 2009, 2 p.m.

For more information: http://www.millersville.edu/~holo-con/ or call Millersville
University, Ms. Maggie Eichler, History Department, 717-872-3555

fulldesc.p: Tickets can be purchased Mon-Fri, 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM at the Student Memorial Center or by calling 717-872-3811 and online at www.MUTicketsOnline.com

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: How far would you go for love? For art? What sacrifices would you make? What price would you be willing to pay? Such are the painful questions explored by Neil LaBute in, The Shape of Things.Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: After a chance meeting in a museum, Evelyn, a sexy, aggressive artist, and Adam, a shy, insecure student, become embroiled in an intense intimacy. Before long, it veers into the kind of dangerous, seductive territory that LaBute does best, as Adam, under Evelyn's steady influence, goes to unimaginable lengths to improve his appearance and character.Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: The Shape of Things challenges our most deeply entrenched ideas about art and love.

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; min-height: 15px; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: Â

p.style: font: normal normal normal 12px/normal 'Times New Roman'; margin: 0px

fulldesc.p: DUE TO SOME LANGUAGE AND SITUATIONS, THIS PLAY IS RECOMMENDED FOR MATURE AUDIENCES.

event.title: Marta L. Sanchez, Painter/Collage Compositions
event.shortdesc: Paintings and collage compositions of artist Marta L. Sanchez Free and open to the public during Ganser Gallery hours
event.fulldesc: Self-taught artist Marta L. Sanchez was born in Panama in 1978. Her paintings are autobiographical, capturing her journey from victim to survivor of sexual violence. Sanchez' art has been an essential tool for self-empowerment and healing. With her work she transforms negative experiences into something useful and positive. Her art focuses on hope, the importance of self-love and the way that we deal with (or ignore) sexual violence. A former lawyer, Sanchez is an activist and now uses her art to further a social consciousness and ultimately seeks to effect change through her work and her background in law. This gallery display is free and open to the public during regular Ganser Gallery hours.

fulldesc.p: WOMEN'S FILM & LECTURE SERIES

Special Event: Mary Haverstick's Home,
with introduction and discussion by the director/producer and the composer/producer
This final event of the Women's Film and Lecture Series celebrates the creativity and resilience of women through a screening and discussion of Mary Haverstick's film Home.Â Selected to premiere at the Montreal Film Festival, Home features Academy Award winner Marsha Gay Harden and her daughter Eulala Scheel in a film shot in Lancaster County.Â Discussion with Director Mary Haverstick and Composer/Producer Michele Mercure after the film.
Reception to follow.
Screening in Memory of Rosario Caminero.Â
Sponsors: Women's Film and Lecture Series.

event.title: ML King Jr. Celebration
event.shortdesc: Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration: Dr. Michael Eric Dyson

fulldesc.h3: Dr. Michael Eric Dyson presentsÂ "Dr. King for the 21st Century"
fulldesc.p: Dr. Michael Eric Dyson is a best-selling author, scholar and cultural critic. Named by Essence magazine as one of the 40 most inspiring African-Americans and by Ebony magazine as one of the 100 most influential black Americans, Dyson is one of the nation's most renowned public intellectuals. The Philadelphia Weekly contends that Dyson "is reshaping what it means to be a public intellectual by becoming the most visible black academic of his time.â When one hears Dyson's name, one thinks of the many hats he wears: prolific author, scholar, public intellectual, ordained minister, media commentator and talk radio show host.
Sponsors: NAACP, Millersville University College, CommissionÂ on Cultural Diversity Black Culture Celebration

event.title: Exhibit: Icons of a Border Installation
event.shortdesc: In time for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Millersville is hosting an exhibition on "Icons of a Border Installation,” a photographic search for traces of the Berlin Wall in today's Berlin.

fulldesc.p: In time for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Millersville is hosting an exhibition on "Icons of a Border Installation,â Â a photographic search for traces of the Berlin Wall in today's Berlin. The exhibition, based on photos taken by students of the University of Paderborn and accompanied by German and English texts, is sponsored by the Goethe Institute and shown in various locations in the US.
The exhibit will be at Millersville until Feb. 13. For more information, please contact Dr. Susanne Nimmrichter, Department of Foreign Languages, at extension 3529.

event.title: Icons of a Border Installation
event.shortdesc: Millersville is hosting an exhibition on "Icons of a Border Installation,” a photographic search for traces of the Berlin Wall in today's Berlin.

fulldesc.p: In time for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Millersville is hosting an exhibition on "Icons of a Border Installation,â Â a photographic search for traces of the Berlin Wall in today's Berlin. The exhibition, based on photos taken by students of the University of Paderborn and accompanied by German and English texts, is sponsored by the Goethe Institute and shown in various locations in the US. To open the exhibit, there will be a presentation by Ms. Cornelia Jarasch, Political and Cultural Affairs Consul, Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany, New York, and Dr. Marianne Washburn, Pedagogical Liaison Officer of the Goethe Institute New York, followed by a reception. The exhibit will be at Millersville until Feb. 13. For more information, please contact Dr. Susanne Nimmrichter, Department of Foreign Languages, at extension 3529.

event.title: Got Game?
event.shortdesc: Ganser Library hosts Got Game?

fulldesc.p: Got Game? BRING IT! - Millersville University Library holds first gaming event

On Thursday, February 5th, 2009, Millersville University's Ganser Library will be hosting its first gaming event "Got Game? BRING IT!âÂ Open to Millersville students, faculty & staff, the event will feature a Wiiâ¢ Rock BandÂ® tournament, Wiiâ¢ bowling, and open-play time.

The event will be held from 8:30 p.m. -11:30 p.m.Â on the third floor of Ganser Library.Â Participants in the Wiiâ¢ Rock BandÂ® tournament are required to pre-register their four person "bandâ on a first come, first serve basis online at: http://www.library.millersville.edu/gamenight/.Â Online registration is now underway.Â

"Students think of the library as a quiet place to study and do research.Â At times, though, it is fun to let off a little steam and get loud even in the library.Â We thought it would be a great idea to take advantage of our central location on campus and give students, staff and faculty an opportunity to participate in a competitive gaming eventâ says event coordinator & MU Learning Technologies Librarian Greg Szczyrbak.

Tournament prizes will be awarded for best band (highest overall score), runner up (second highest overall score), and best performance (most entertaining single song presentation).Â In addition, refreshments will be available so come to participate or just cheer on your friends!

The gaming event will be hosted by Millersville University Library. Please check the Millersville University Library Facebook page for more details.Â To host your event at the library or for other information, please contact Library Outreach at (717)872-3617 or Library.Outreach@Millersville.edu.

event.title: Red Dress Luncheon
event.shortdesc: Red Dress Luncheon on campus in support of National Wear Red Day.

fulldesc.p: Faculty, staff and students are invited to the third annual Red Dress Luncheon on February 6.Â Millersville University's Wellness Committee and the President's Commission on the Status of Women sponsor the luncheon in support of National Wear Red Day, a day when Americans nationwide wear red to show their support for heart disease awareness.Â The luncheon will be held from 11:30 a.m. 1 p.m. in Lehr, Gordinier.Â Tickets are $8 for a "Heart Healthy Meal.âÂ For more information contact Deb Miller at deb.miller@millersville.edu.Â

event.title: "An Evening of Latino Performing Arts"
event.shortdesc: Come out for an evening of Latino performing arts with classical guitarist Ernesto Tamayo and poet Dr. Marco Antolin. Free and open to the public.
event.fulldesc: Come out for an evening of Latino performing arts with classical guitarist Ernesto Tamayo and poet Dr. Marco Antolin. Free and open to the public. Ernesto Tamayo has toured extensively throughout North and South America and Europe. He is one of the most accomplished and sought-after guitarists of his generation. Tamayo is often praised for his brilliant technique, artistry and his brilliant technique, artistry, and his exceptionally warm tone and expressive interpretations on guitar. Born in Havana, Cuba, Tamayo began studying the guitar with his father when he was five. He made his television debut at the young age of nine. Dr. Marco Antolin, faculty member in the foreign languages department and specialist in 20th century Spanish poetry, will read his poetic works. Sponsored by Cultural Affairs Committee, Latino/a Studies Minor and Foreign Languages Department.

event.title: Candidate Dr. Robert Smith Visitation
event.shortdesc: Candidate for the Dean of Science and Mathematics, Dr. Robert Smith

fulldesc.p: The Search committee for the Dean of Science and Mathematics is pleased to announce that the following candidate has been invited for a campus interview. All members of the University community are welcome to attend the public forum session. The candidate's credentials are available for your review at the Reserve Desk in Ganser Library and in the office of the Dean of the School of Science and Mathematics in Caputo 206. The Search Committee urges all who participate in the process share their views with the Committee by completing Candidate Evaluation Sheets, available at each session, or by communicating directly with a member of the Committee.

Candidates have been asked to give a thirty-minute presentation on the following topic:Â "The Role of the Science and Mathematics Dean." The forum will include opportunities for questions and answers.

Dr. Robert T. Smith
Campus Visit: 12-13 February 2009
Open Public Forum: Thursday, 12 February 2009
3:30 - 5:00 p.m., McComsey Hall, Myers Auditorium, Room 260

Dr. Robert Smith received his Ph.D. in mathematics in 1982 from the University of Delaware and joined the faculty at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University in Blacksburg, VA shortly thereafter as an assistant professor of mathematics. After five years at VPI, Smith was hired as an associate professor of mathematics at Millersville University of Pennsylvania. In 1992 Smith was promoted to professor of mathematics at MU and became chairperson of the Department of Mathematics in 1999, a position that he retains today. Dr. Smith served as Acting Dean of the School of Science and Mathematics from July 2003 through July 2004. Dr. Smith has 10 years of experience in an academic leadership position.

event.title: Film: Cabin in the Sky
event.shortdesc: Film: Cabin in the Sky
event.fulldesc:
SPRING FILM SERIES: Exploring Privilege, Ideology, and Power: A Case Study of African Americans in the Media
Cabin in the Sky Â "An all-star screen adaptation of the successful Broadway play, Cabin in the Sky (1943) tells the story of the gambler Little Joe who is seriously wounded in a barroom fight. His pious wife, Petunia, prays for him to have a second chance so he can get into heaven. Joe survives, but God's General and Lucifer, Jr. begin the battle for his soul. - Cast: Ethel Waters (Petunia Jackson), Eddie "Rochester" Anderson (Little Joe), Lena Horne (Georgia Brown), Louis Armstrong (The Trumpeter), Rex Ingram (Lucius, Lucifer, Jr.), Butterfly McQueen (Lily), Ruby Dandridge (Mrs. Kelso), Duke Ellington and His Orchestra.âÂ Source:http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article.jsp?cid=17710&mainArticleId=133204
Free and open to the public.
Sponsors: African American Studies, Cultural Affairs Committee, Humanities Film Series, University Theme Committee.Â

event.title: Black Maria Film Festival
event.shortdesc: Massage your soul with the Black Maria Film Festival on 2/15 at 3 p.m.

fulldesc.p: From biting commentary to high caliber films, the Black Maria film festival is sure to impress even the most stubborn movie critic.

The festival is coming to Millersville University on Sunday, February 15, at 3 p.m. and will include 90 minutes of films and lots of discussion. Located in Meyers Auditorium in McComsey Hall, those attending are able to experience the new and improved Bose sound and projection system recently installed.

Black Maria brings artists to life, and is a unique experience where film lovers are able to receive insider information on a smattering of films that "somehow, some way, touch you,â explained Ben Cunningham, art.

The festival will meet for good food, coffee and commentary at Myers Auditorium in McComsey Hall. With help from the School of Humanities and Social Sciences that made the festival possible, this date marks the second Black Maria stop at Millersville University. The event is advertised on the university's cultural event calendar, and classes are also able to attend the festival as a cultural event.

The festival brings out the idea that art is a cathartic experience, and is something that cannot be put into words. Cunningham said the films make viewers feel "like someone reached inside you and massaged your soul.â

Each film ranges from one and a half minutes to 20 minutes long, and is a unique experience into the mind of the artist.Â The festival is free and open to the public. For more information on the festival, contact Cunningham at #3488 or email ben.cunningham@millersville.edu.
Â

event.title: Sculptor Iain Machell at Millersville University
event.shortdesc: On Monday, February 16, Millersville University presents international sculptor Iain Machell.

fulldesc.p: Machell will be showing his recent drawings and sculptures, along with giving a lecture called "Iain and Ian,â named after himself and artist Ian Hamilton Finlay. Machell's sculptures are called "landscape interventionsâ and are made of found materials like wood or stone that are removed from the natural environment, altered and then replaced in the landscape.

Machell teaches and is the chair of Visual Arts, Music & Theatre at SUNY Ulster, Stone Ridge, N.Y. Â He has eight years of formal art training, including a degree in art from Portsmount College in England, Grays School of Art in Scotland and a master's in sculpture from the University of Albany, SUNY.
The presentation begins at 11:30 p.m. and ends 1 p.m. in Sykes Gallery. There will be a lunch time lecture at noon.

The candidate's credentials are available for your review at the Reserve Desk in Ganser Library and in the office of the Dean of the School of Science and Mathematics in Caputo 206. The Search Committee urges all who participate in the process share their views with the Committee by completing Candidate Evaluation Sheets, available at each session, or by communicating directly with a member of the Committee.

Dr. Richard M. Kreminski
Campus Visit: 16-17 February 2009
Open Public Forum: Monday, 16 February 2009
3:30 5:00 p.m., Ford Atrium, McComsey Hall

Dr. Richard M. Kreminski received his Ph.D. in applied mathematics in 1994 from the University of Maryland and JD in 2008 from the Dedman School of Law, Southern Methodist University with an emphasis on intellectual property. He rose through the ranks from a tenure-track assistant professor in 1995 to his present position as professor of mathematics at the Texas A&M University-Commerce (formerly East Texas State Univ.). He has been head of the department of mathematics since 2003. Dr. Kreminski also served a three year term as assistant dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, followed by a one year appointment as interim dean. He applies to the Dean's position with 10 years of academic leadership experience.

Dr. Roger Byrne
Campus Visit: 19-20 February 2009

3:30 5:00 p.m., Ford Atrium, McComsey Hall

Dr. Roger Byrne received his Ph.D. in Zoology/Physiology from Louisiana State University in 1988. He started his professional career as a visiting research professor at Louisiana State and the University of Plymouth (UK) before moving on to SUNY-Fredonia in 1991, where he was awarded the rank of professor in 2005. Since 1999, Byrne has served in a number of administrative positions including a year as interim chair, three years as interim Dean of Natural and Social Sciences and Professional Studies, two years as chair of the biology department and one year as Director of Campus Assessment. For the past 2.5 years he has been the Director of Science Education Partnership. In all, Dr. Byrne has 10 years experience in a position of academic leadership.

event.title: The Vagina Monologues
event.shortdesc: The Vagina Monologues is a performance done on thousands of college and university campuses worldwide since 1998. Millersville University has been a participant since 2001, and this year's performance will feature dramatic sketches performed by women at MU.

fulldesc.p: The performances are designed for both men and women, with the purpose of raising awareness about violence against women and girls.Â

The Vagina Monologue performances and complimenting events have raised millions of dollars for local charities over the past 10 years. Here at Millersville University, proceeds from The Vagina Monologue performances and complimenting events will benefit the Milagro House (http://www.milagrohouse.org/), a transitional facility in Lancaster for women and children and the Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster (http://www.dvslanc.org/).

MU IS (1 per ID) - $5.00
Tickets are available for purchase online at www.muticketsonline.com or by calling the Student Memorial Center Box Office at 717-872-3811 Monday thru Friday from 8AM to 4PM.

Dr. Joseph Merola received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1978. The first eight years of his professional career he was a research chemist and then senior chemist for Exxon Research. After a brief visiting associate position at CalTech, he joined the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (VPI) in 1987, and achieved the rank of professor of chemistry in 1995. From 1998-2001 he served as Associate Dean for Research and Outreach for the College of Arts and Sciences at VPI, and in 2001 became Acting Dean of the Graduate School for one year. In 2002, Dr. Merola became a Senior Administrative Fellow in charge of university restructuring. Since 2003, Dr Merola has served VPI as Chair of the Chemistry Department. He applies to the Dean's position with 11 years of academic leadership experience.

event.title: Mendelssohn 200th Birthday celebration
event.shortdesc: The Millersville University Music Department is celebrating the 200th birthday of Felix Mendelssohn with a faculty chamber music concert on Feb. 8.

fulldesc.p: The Millersville University Music Department is celebrating the 200th birthday of Felix Mendelssohn with a faculty chamber music concert on Feb. 8.
Mendelssohn was a prolific composer, fine pianist, improviser and landscape artist. He made significant contributions to solo piano, vocal, choral, symphonic and chamber ensemble literature.

The concert will feature Dr. Christy Banks, clarinet, Laurie Reese, cello, Reuben Blundell, violin and Dr. Anita Renfroe, piano. Dr. Philip Tacka will provide comments on the composer’s life and works. The program is dedicated to the memory of Dr. Jeanne Elder. The program is free and the public is cordially invited to attend. For more information, please contact Dr. Anita Renfroe, music, at 717-872-3370.

event.title: Candidate Dr. Inno Onwueme Visitation
event.shortdesc: Candidate for the Dean of Science and Mathematics, Dr. Inno Onwueme

fulldesc.p: The Search committee for the Dean of Science and Mathematics is pleased to announce that the following candidate has been invited for a campus interview. All members of the University community are welcome to attend the public forum session. The candidate's credentials are available for your review at the Reserve Desk in Ganser Library and in the office of the Dean of the School of Science and Mathematics in Caputo 206. The Search Committee urges all who participate in the process share their views with the Committee by completing Candidate Evaluation Sheets, available at each session, or by communicating directly with a member of the Committee.

Candidates have been asked to give a thirty-minute presentation on the following topic:Â "The Role of the Science and Mathematics Dean." The forum will include opportunities for questions and answers.

Dr. Inno Onwueme
Campus Visit: 9-10 March 2009
Open Public Forum: Monday, 9 March 2009
2:30 4:00 p.m., Ford Atrium, McComsey Hall

Dr. Innocent Onwueme received his Ph.D. in Plant Physiology in 1969 from the University of California, Davis. After a one year post-doc position, Dr. Onwueme began his professional career in 1970 as an assistant professor at the University of Ife (now Awolowo University), Nigeria. By 1977 he had ascended to the position of department head and professor in the department of plant science. He moved on to the Federal University of Technology, Owerri where he served six years as Dean of the College of Agriculture and Agriculture Technology and one year as Dean of the Graduate School. Dr. Onwueme spent seven years as head of the department of agriculture at the University of Technology in Papua, New Guinea; four years as director of the Fulton Center for Sustainable Living at Wilson College, PA; and two years as director of the Missouri State Fruit Experiment Station. He now serves as associate dean and professor in the College of Natural and Applied Sciences at Missouri State University.

event.title: A Showcase of Scholarship 2009 Opening Reception
event.shortdesc: Please join us in celebrating Millersville University's faculty and staff scholarly and creative works while also enjoying refreshments and the sounds of Millersville University's guitar ensemble!

fulldesc.p:
On Monday, March 16, 2009 from 3:00-5:00 p.m., Millersville University Library will celebrate the exhibit opening of Millersville University: A Showcase of Scholarship 2009. This annual reception celebrates the depth and breadth of scholarly and creative works here at Millersville University by launching a unique display on the library's first floor.
The opening reception (March 16th from 3-5PM)as well as the exhibit (March 16th through April 30th) are both free and open to the public. Please join us to celebrate this exhibit opening, enjoy refreshments with visitors, and stroll through the display of scholarly and creative works to the sound of Millersville University's guitar ensemble.
The exhibit will consist of scholarly and creative works submitted by Millersville faculty and staff members. Items include published works (monographs, articles, poems, chapters); unpublished works (conference papers, texts or notes of speeches, musical compositions); records of other activities (catalogs, photographs, or slides of exhibits or individual works of art, programs or recordings of performances); and other scholarly and creative works from all Millersville employees (sculptures, jewelry, films, posters).
These items will be on display in the Millersville University Library during the months of March and April. Upon close of the exhibit in May, some of these items will be added to the Millersville Authors Collection, a collection devoted to preserving the scholarly and creative activities of the University community.
This event is jointly sponsored by the Center for Academic Excellence, the Office of the Provost, and the Millersville University Library.

event.title: Anna Funk Lockey Lecture- Dr. William Ayers
event.shortdesc: William Ayers, Distinguished Professor of Education and Senior University Scholar at the University of Illinois at Chicago will discuss urban education.

fulldesc.p: On March 19, 2009 Dr. William Ayers will give the Anna Funk Lockey Education Lecture at Millersville University.Â

Dr. Ayers is a Distinguished Professor of Education and Senior University Scholar at the University of Illinois at Chicago and founder of both the Small Schools Workshop and the Center for Youth and Society.Â Â Dr. Ayers was chosen as this year's speaker because of the outstanding work he has done in the field of urban education over the past 20 years.Â He was selected by the Academic Cultural Enrichment Committee housed in the School of Education. The School of Education is in the process of revitalizing their urban education concentration for pre-service teachers and was pleased to have the opportunity to have such an outstanding advocate join them to discuss ways to connect with urban students, parents and teachers.
Â
Dr.Â Ayers worked with Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley in shaping the city's school reform program, and was one of three co-authors of the Chicago Annenberg Challenge grant proposal that in 1995 won $49.2 million over five years for public school reform.Â In 1997 Chicago awarded him its Citizen of the Year award for his work on the project.Â Since 1999 he has served on the board of directors of the Woods Fund of Chicago, an anti-poverty, philanthropic foundation established as the Woods Charitable Fund in 1941.
Â

event.title: Film: La Haine
event.shortdesc: Film: La Haine
event.fulldesc:
SPRING FILM SERIES: Exploring Privilege, Ideology, and Power: A Case Study of African Americans in the Media
La Haine"La Haine - is one of the most blisteringly effective pieces of urban cinema ever made. Fluid black-and-white camera work captures 24 hours in the Paris projects. After an Arab boy is taken to hospital with a gunshot wound, a Jewish skinhead, Vinz (Vincent Cassel), gets his hands on a police revolver and threatens to use it to avenge his buddy. His friends, Hubert (Hubert KoundÃ©) and Said (Said Taghmaoui), hang out and riff about nothing in particular, caught up in the daily struggle against crippling ennui. But the gun casts a shadow over even the most frivolous conversation, lending a sense of near-palpable foreboding to this exceptionally powerful film.âÂ
Â Source: Wendy Ide, London TimesFree and open to the public.
Â

event.title: Women in Math and Science Conference
event.shortdesc: Women in Math and Science Conference featuring Dr. Janice Cuny.

fulldesc.p: On Tuesday, March 31, 2009 the Women in Math and Science Conference, held at Millersville University of Pennsylvania, will feature keynote speaker Dr. Janice Cuny. A program officer at the National Science Foundation since 2004, she also served as a faculty member in computer science at Purdue University, the University of Massachusetts and the University of Oregon.

Cuny explains her talk at the conference will be about, "the status of women in computing, the reasons for their underrepresentation and a possible agenda for change.â She served as the co-chair for the Computing Research Association's Committee on the Status of Women, and as a member of the Advisory Board for Anita Borg Institute for Woman and Technology and the Leadership team of the National Center for Women in Technology.

For Cuny's efforts with underserved populations, she received one of the 2006 Association for Computing Machinery President's Awards and the 2007 Computing Research Association A. Nico Habermann Award.
The keynote presentation will be held from 9 a.m. to 10 a.m. in the Student Memorial Center Multipurpose Room. Admission to the lecture is free.
For more information, contact Susan Thomas, School of Science and Mathematics, at susan.thomas@millersville.edu.

event.title: The State of the Universe
event.shortdesc: As part of the International Year of Astronomy in 2009, marking 400 years since Galileo's first observations, Millersville University presents the Harlow Shapley Visiting Lectureship.

fulldesc.p: How Old Is the Universe? Find Out!

As part of the International Year of Astronomy in 2009, marking 400 years since Galileo's first observations, Millersville University of Pennsylvania's physics department presents the Harlow Shapley Visiting Lectureship on April 1, 2009.

This astronomy lecture is by Dr. John Huchra, professor of cosmology at Harvard University and President of the American Astronomical Society. Huchra will speak on "The State of the Universe," discussing the age and fate of the universe and explaining the theories and observations of its origins.

The talk will be in Meyer's Auditorium in McComsey hall at 7:15 p.m. on April 1. This event is free and open to the public, and suitable for all audiences. For more information, please contact Dr. Sean Hendrick, Sean.Hendrick@millersville.edu or 717-872-3412.

event.title: Public Weather Awareness Day
event.shortdesc: The First Annual MU-AMS Public Weather Awareness Day is a fun weather learning experience for children and families and is free and open to the public!
event.fulldesc:
The First Annual Millersville University Chapter of the American Meteorological Society Public Weather Awareness Day is an afternoon full of celebrating and experiencing everything about the weather. This event is designed for children and families, free and open to the general public from 1-5pm on Sunday, April 5th at Pucillo Gymnasium on the campus of Millersville University.
Come produce your own weathercast in front of a green screen, participate in a trivia contest, see hands-on demonstrations, cool weather-related experiments and more. Also, you will have the opportunity to meet and talk with people who make a living forecasting and watching the weather every day! Don't miss it!

event.title: Violence Against Women and Girls Amid the Violence in the DRC
event.shortdesc: Bukeni Tete Waruzi is coming to speak about the conflict in the DRC and its affect on women and girls.
event.fulldesc:
Bukeni Tete Waruzi will be speaking about the violence perpetrated against women and girls in the Democratic Republic of Congo. He has done a lot of work with girls stuck in the horrors of a conflict that has been raging for over a decade. Come learn from a history maker about the reality for those living in a war zone.
Bukeni is a native of Uvira, in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. He is currently writing a book "Negotiate with Devils to Release Angels," a memoir of his 10-years of activism demobilizing child soldiers in eastern DRC. He founded and served as the Executive Director of Ajedi-Ka/Child Soldiers Project, an organization working to decommission and reintegrate child soldiers into society. Bukeni has also produced several films on child soldiers and the spread of HIV/AIDS. Bukeni is currently Program Coordinator for Africa and the Middle East for the international organization WITNESS and has done work with the European Union and the United Nations. Bukeni was also a main actor in the construction and implementation of international laws regarding the recruitment and use of child soldiers through the International Criminal Court.
And just in case knowledge gained through the rare opportunity is not a good enough motivator to attend-
FREE FOOD will also be provided!

event.title: 2009 Paul J. McInerney Lecture at Millersville
event.shortdesc: Expert on weather and flying to speak at Millersville.

fulldesc.p: On Thursday, April 9 Millersville University's Department of Earth Sciences will host the Paul J. McInerney Memorial Lecture, featuring guest speaker Dr. Marcia Politovich.

Politovich is the deputy director of Aviation Applications National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Co. An expert in cloud physics, winter storms and aviation weather, she will speak on aircraft icing, a recent news topic. Politovich will also touch on the problem of diagnosing and forecasting in flight icing conditions, highlighting current research being performed by the National Center for Atmospheric Research. Most of all, she will explain how recent technologies and improving forecast methods will benefit the public.

The 2009 McInerney Memorial Lecture will take place in Caputo 210, Armstrong Auditorium from 4:30 p.m. until 5:30 p.m. at Millersville University. Refreshments will be available in Caputo Lobby at 4 p.m. This lecture is free and open to the public.

event.title: Disney College Program E-Presentation
event.shortdesc: Come learn about the internship of a lifetime with Walt Disney World Resorts and Disneyland Resorts!
event.fulldesc: The Disney Theme Parks and Resorts College Program at the Walt Disney World Resort is a one-of-a-kind, Disney-designed combination of education and work experience. We're looking for exceptional, ambitious students who have a genuine enthusiasm for their professional futures and who love to make people smile. In addition to the experience gained working as a Disney Cast Member, participants in the Disney College Program at the Walt Disney World Resort will have the opportunity to meet Disney leaders. With a chance to earn credit, stand out on a resume, and have advanced opportunities for growth, the Disney College Program also offers the chance to make life-long friends and experience first-hand the magic of Disney!

event.title: Lecture: Alexander Reyna - NYC Artist/Game Designer
event.shortdesc: Alexander Reyna - a NYC artist and game designer will speak on April 10.
event.fulldesc:
Alexander will break down some of his work into discreet parts and talk about how he comes to the final image. He will start from a video still and work backwards into the logos and other designs. He'll discuss his new work (the conspiracy theory) and then talk about the relationship between art and design, and discuss his gaming/social networking projects.
Alexander Reyna was born in Africa, and came to the United States when he was six. He received his BFA in Painting from the University of New Hampshire and his MFA in Painting from Pratt Institute. His earliest computer was the TRS-80 and his digital skills are autodidactic. He lives and works in New York City.
Alexander Reyna has had solo exhibitions in New York and exhibitions throughout the United States and overseas. He has participated in group shows including Spaces/Cleveland, The DIVA Art Fair, The Scope Art Fair, Hunter College, and several prominent American Universities. Reyna has been featured and reviewed in interviews and publications including PS1, New York Arts Magazine, The Village Voice, NPR, and Animal Magazine. He was an Assistant Professor at Mercy College and taught in the Master's program at New York University. He is currently on the teaching faculty at the School of Visual Arts.

event.title: Darfur: An Intimate Look (An Evening with Gretchen Steidle Wallace)
event.shortdesc: Gretchen Steidle Wallace will speak about her work in Chad with the Darfuri refugees.
event.fulldesc:
Gretchen will speak about her work in Chad with the Darfuri refugees. First, there will be a viewing of the film, The Devil Came on Horseback, an award winning documentary including her brother, Brian Steidle. See first hand footage of the atrocities raging in the Western Sudanese region.
Inspired by her work in South Africa and her brother's tenure as a military observer in Darfur, Sudan, she established Global Grassroots. Global Grassroots is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization which provides social entrepreneurship training and seed funding to help disadvantaged women start their own ideas for social change. Gretchen returned to Africa with her brother in 2005 to launch Global Grassroots work in the Darfur refugee camps of eastern Chad, and in 2006 to Rwanda to offer social venture training to survivors of genocide.Â
The Devil Came on Horseback premiered at the Sundance Film Festival in 2007, was broadcast on the National Geographic Channel, BBC, Canal Plus and in over 30 countries. Gretchen is also co-author with her brother of his memoirs, also titled The Devil Came on Horseback, which was published by PublicAffairs in March 2007. In 2007, she was honored by World Business Magazine and Shell as one of the top International 35 Women Under 35.
Refreshments will be served!

event.title: One Woman Show - A Play of One's Own
event.shortdesc: Title: A Play of One's Own Performance Credits: Written by Barbara Bejoian Performed by Laura Korach Howell Original Direction by Melanie Jones

fulldesc.p:
Performance Credits: Written by Barbara Bejoian
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Performed by Laura Korach Howell
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Original Direction by Melanie Jones
Date: Tuesday, April 14th, 2009 at 7 p.m.

Sponsored by:Â Students Cultural Affairs Committee
Gender and Women's Studies Program
Students in EDFN 376
Performance Location:Â Rafters Theatre Dutcher Hall, Millersville University

Bio: Laura Korach HowellÂ
Laura is an Equity actor, teacher, director and playwright. She received her professional training at Circle-in-the-Square Professional Theatre School (NYC), The Actor's Center (NYC) and Shakespeare & Co. (MA).Â She was the Director of Theatre at Lancaster Country Day School from '97- '06 and is a faculty member at The Fulton Academy as well as a roster artist with the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. She was most recently seen as Shylock in The Merchant of Venice (TSS). Her one-woman show, Shakespeare's World, Women & Significant Others, was accepted to be part of the Pennsylvania Humanities Council's Commonwealth Speaker program. Laura is the executive director of The People's Shakespeare Project, an organization dedicated to furthering an appreciation and understanding of William Shakespeare's texts through performances and performance-based instruction.

About The Play: A Play of One's Own, Written by Barbara Bejoian, Acted by Laura Korach Howell, Original Direction by Melanie Jones
Laura Korach Howell, local Equity actress, teacher and director, reprises the role of the famous and beloved British novelist, Virginia Woolf, in the one-woman show, "A Play of One's Ownâ- based on the life of Virginia Woolf.

Howell, playwright Barbara Bejoian and director Melanie Jones worked together and premiered the production at Leeds Theatre at Brown University (Providence, RI) in 1981 with great success. It went on to subsequent productions in Rhode Island, Florida and Pennsylvania, and a memorable run at Lancaster's own CoMotion Theatre in 1992.Â Â Laura revisited this role in 2008 at Theatre of the Seventh Sister and found the ensuing years had only added to the richness and depth of the role.

The play delves deeply into the life of Virginia Woolf her writing, her family and friends, the Bloomsbury years, her lovers and her struggles with mental illness. It is the story of a life fully & creatively lived. Come meet the woman who wrote so many groundbreaking novels and discover who she really was.Â You might know of her as the person who was plagued with bouts of madness or as a member of the Bloomsbury elite of London or as an early feminist or as an intellectual force.Â But she transcends all labels.Â She lived an incredibly full, loving, creative life and has valuable lessons to share.Â Audiences have responded enthusiastically to the play as it speaks to everyone on very personal levels. It is a clear-eyed view of what it is to be truly human. There is no need to be a Virginia Woolf aficionado to appreciate the play. Those who are new to the author will find much to savor, as those familiar with the life and times of Virginia Woolf.

William Gale, who reviewed for The Providence Journal-Bulletin, said: "It is a splendid exploration of life and character that no one who loves taut, truthful theatre ought to miss. Howell presents her (Woolf) as flesh and blood. She does not skirt her prissiness but shows us the passion underneath it.â

event.title: Spring Choral Concert
event.shortdesc: Spring Choral Concert

fulldesc.p:
Millersville University's spring choral concert, under the direction of Dr. Jeffrey Gemmell, will be held on Sunday, April 26, in Lyte Auditorium, Alumni Hall. The year's concert, entitled "Enlightenment and Illumination," will features retiring Music Faculty member Professor Jean Bradel, also features two major contemporary choral masterworks that anchor a spiritually rich and emotionally intense program. One of these works is Robert Convery's cantata Songs of Children, written in memory of all children who perished in the Holocaust.
The text of Songs of Children is a compilation of nine poems written by children while interned at Terezin Concentration Camp. Â The purpose of this cantata is eloquently stated by a passage from Deuteronomy that opens the work: "Only take heed, and keep your soul diligently, lest you forget the things which your eyes have seen, and lest they depart from your hearts all the days of your life; make them known to your children and your children's children.â Â The nine poems in Songs of Children follow a child's spiritual transformation from the moment they enter a concentration camp. Â The initial naive state of entry is followed by a brutal confrontation with reality. Â Finally, a transcendence of that harsh reality is obtained. Â This piece exemplifies the triumph of the human spirit through the eyes of children.
Morten Lauridsen's Lux Aeterna will conclude this year's choral concert. Â This five movement piece has texts drawn from sacred Latin sources, each containing references to light. Â The inner movements of the work are drawn respectively from the Te Deum, O Nata Lux, and Veni, Sancte Spiritus of the Requiem Mass.
Following Professor Jean Bradel's retirement follows thirty and a half years of teaching and service in Millersville University's department of music. Professor Bradel will perform "Inflammatus et accensusâ from Rossini's Stabat Mater with the Millersville University Choir. Â Alumni are invited to sing with the choir for this exciting collaboration as well as attend a reception and dinner following the concert. Â The reception, held in honor of Professor Bradel's service to Millersville University and the community, will be hosted in the University and Kline Dining Rooms in Bolger Conference Center of Gordinier. Â There will be a cocktail reception at 5:00 p.m. followed by a special guest recital at 5:30 p.m. Â A dinner/roast will be held at 6:15 p.m. Â Money raised from the reception will be incorporated into the "Jean Bradel Vocal Scholarship.â Â Anyone interested in attending, please contact Dianne O'Connor, Director of Alumni Services at 717-872-3352.Â Â
Sunday, April 26, 2009 at 2:30 p.m.

event.title: What the Twitter
event.shortdesc: Educating and empowering yourself to be savvy and safe online will be the topic of a lecture on May 18 on campus.

fulldesc.p: Educating and empowering yourself to be savvy and safe online will be the topic of a lecture on May 18 on campus.Â Millersville's Dr. Nazli Hardy and Penn Manor's Charlie Reisinger will present "What the 'Twitter.âÂ The lecture on online safety will be held in the University's Student Memorial Center's multi-purpose room at 7 p.m.Â It is free and open to the public.

This event is part of an ongoing lecture series by the Millersville University- Penn Manor CyberPartnership.Â One of the goals is to connect the community to computing and technology.Â The partnership was recently named as a Distinguished Award winner by the Civic and Community Engagement and Research.

"Our purpose is to make the most recent developments in the field of information science available to the community,â said Hardy, computer science. "We hope to educate the public about the powerful applications of Web 2.0 and social networking as well as the dangers they pose and how this can impact the rest of their lives. We also want to provide awareness of the current applications to parents in order to empower them to protect their children.â
For more information please visit http://cs.millersville.edu/activities/mupmpart or contact Dr. Nazli Hardy at Nazli.Hardy@Millersville.edu or http://cs.millersville.edu/fs/nhardy/

event.title: Congress to Campus (C2C)
event.shortdesc: Join CCERP in Hosting two former members of the US Congress as they visit MU!

fulldesc.p: Join CCERP in Hosting two former members of the US Congress as they visit Millersville University! The Hon. Ken Hechler (D-WV) 1958-76 and Hon. Ron Sarasin R-CT, 1968-72 will grace our campus and are eager to meet Millersville students. "Being principled and being practical-Has politics become too adversarial?" an open discussion forum featuring the former members of congress will be held on September 14, 2009 from 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. in the Lehr dining room of Gordinier Hall.Â This event is part of Pizza, Policy and Politics and will allow the public and students to converse with The Hon. Ken Hechler D-WV 1958-76 and Hon. Ron Sarasin R-CT, 1968-72.

Hechler was elected US Congressman of West Virginia and was re-elected for eighteen years. He served four, four-year terms as the West Virginia Secretary of State, was the only Congressman to march with Martin Luther King in Selma, Alabama and focused on the fight against corruption in the coal union. Hechler is noted for his efforts to eradicate corruption in politics and assisting the mobilization of secretaries of state and attourney generals in 33 states to limit campaign spending.

Sarasin served three terms as a member of Congress, representing the Fifth District of Connecticut, and two terms representing the Connecticut General Assembly.Â Sarasin is currently the president and Chief Executive Officer of the United States Capitol Historical Society, a non-profit, non-partisan, educational entity attracting young people to careers in public service.
Congress to Campus 2009 is part of the American Democracy project.

event.title: Ryan Kelly Art Exhibit
event.shortdesc: "I Reserve the Right to Contradict Myself" a mixed media piece, something of a self portrait in two parts, title from a William Saroyan short story.

fulldesc.p: Ryan Kelly "I Reserve the Right to Contradict Myself" exhibit Sept. 14, 2009 to Oct. 15, 2009.

Ryan Kelly is a native son of the great state of Michigan, but currently resides under the shadow of the Liberty Bell and The Ben Franklin Bridge, in Philadelphia PA. where he is an Artist In Residence at The Clay Studio. He holds a BFA in Ceramics from the Kansas City Art Institute, and an MFA in Ceramics from The Ohio State University. He was also for a year, the Lourmina Salter Fellow at the Baltimore Clayworks. Ryan has taught both on the community level at a number of institutions, and at the collegiate level at The Ohio State University, Swarthmore College and now the Maryland Institute College of Art. The wide variety of materials and communities in which he works has led to his involvement with several puppet theaters and theatrical prop construction for low budget films. He also enjoys having facial hair and speaking in the third person.

link.name: Sykes Gallery - Free and open to the public.

event.title: A Class Apart
event.shortdesc: Screening of "A Class Apart: Mexican American Civil Rights"

fulldesc.p: "A Class Apart" video screening, September 17, 2009 from 7-9 pm.

In honor of Constitution Day and Hispanic Heritage Month, the video "A Class Apart" will be shown. In 1954, the landmark case Hernandez v. Texas was heard before the U.S. Supreme Court. Attorneys for the Mexican American plaintiff argued that Mexican Americans, although defined as white by the U.S. government, were a distinct class in the existing binary racial system. They argued that current Jim Crow style policies and practices in Texas violated their rights under the 14th amendment. The video chronicles the court case, the attorneys who plead the case, and the watershed court decision.
Students from LATS 201 Introduction to Latino/a Studies and Dr. Kimberly Mahaffy will facilitate a discussion of the video.
Sponsors: The Latino/a Studies Minor, The Rosario Caminero Latino Celebration Committee, Humanities Film Series, Society on Latino Affairs.

The series will feature ten scheduled researchers and speakers ending December 12.
This event is free, open to the public and sponsored by Millersville's biology department.

event.title: Angela Rossi and jazz group C’est si bon
event.shortdesc: This ensemble of extremely talented musicians will take you on a tour through the traditional French music that has nurtured in the hearts and homes of France for centuries!

fulldesc.p: France has for long been considered a center for European art and music. The aim of this show is to connect the listener to the deep meaning and expression of the French "chanson" of Michel Legrand, Jacques PrÃ©vert, Edith Piaf and other legendary musicians and poets. This concert captures the true essence of French popular classics like "Milord" with a little bit of jazz spin to them. Upon listening, you will suddenly find yourself in Belleville, Paris, the ethnically diverse district described by Daniel Pennac. Here you will feel the atmosphere of the "banlieue parisienne" where people lead eccentric and creative lives!

This show has already been performed with great success at well-known theaters and concert halls throughout the United States, such as the Count Basie Theatre (NJ), the Bergen Performing Arts Center (NJ), The Egg Hart Theatre (NY), Irvine Hall (PA), and the Berklee Performance Center (Boston, MA). This ensemble of extremely talented musicians will take you on a tour through the traditional French music that has nurtured in the hearts and homes of France for centuries!

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Priorities
event.shortdesc: Examined Life: Philosophy in the Streets (2008) - Part of Reflect and Connect Series. This event is free and open to the public

fulldesc.p: Astra Taylor updates Socrates' idea that "the unexamined life is not worth livingâ by filming modern-day philosophers discussing current issues like consumerism and ethics, man's relation to nature, animal rights, revolution, postmodern anxiety, globalization, disability rights, and the role of philosophy in our postmodern world. Featured theorists include Cornel West, Avital Ronell, Peter Singer, Kwarne Anthony Appiah, Martha Nussbaum, Michael Hardt, Slavoj Zizek, and Judith Butler with disability-rights activist Sunaura Taylor.

Free and open to the public. Post-screening discussion facilitators include Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies, and Dr. Chuck Ward, Associate Professor of Philosophy. Sponsored by the Millersville University Library and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences. Complements the CCERP Reflect & Connect Series.
For More Information: See the Humanities Film Series webpage or join us on the Humanities Film Series Facebook page.

event.title: National Depression Screening Day
event.shortdesc: Millersville University's counseling center will be offering free depression screenings from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. in Lyle Hall.

fulldesc.p:
As part of National Depression Screening Day on Sept. 30, 2009, the counseling center in Lyle Hall will be offering depression screenings from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. Students will have the opportunity to complete a written self-assessment and meet one-on-one with a mental health professional. Educational materials will also be available to take home. Additional counseling will be recommended for those who appear to need further evaluation.
National Depression Screening Day, held every October as part of Mental Illness Awareness Week, is a program of Screening for Mental HealthÂ®, a nonprofit organization based in Wellesley, Massachusetts. Last year, more than 76,000 students were screened at colleges across the country as part of the NDSD.

Students, faculty and staff are welcome to come by to check out local non-profit agencies in Lancaster who will be showcasing service that they've done in the community. event.title: Reducing Violent Crime
event.shortdesc: Reducing Violent Crime Associated with Overt Drug Markets: Focused Deterrence, Community Partnerships, and Data Driven Policing focuses on High Point, N.C. and their success of reducing violent crime approximately 40 percent.

fulldesc.p:
High Point, North Carolina has closed four open air drug markets and reduced violent crime approximately 40 percent. High Point police and community have created a close partnership, the adoption of an innovative deterrence model, and an open, transparent analysis of data to determine target areas and subsequent monitoring, leading to the success of a decline in violent crimes. The program has won several national awards and is being replicated in numerous cities, Lancaster City being one.
The lecture, given by Dr. Lee Hunt, Crime Analyst for High Point, N.C. Police Department, will illustrate the elements that comprise the program, data analysis, results and how the program has been applied to other public safety concerns.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Violent Crime Reduction Initiative
event.shortdesc: Crime analyst, Dr. Lee Hunt, from High Point, N.C., police department, will give a lecture on reducing violent crime.

p.strong: Violent Crime Reduction Initiative to Lancaster

fulldesc.p: Crime analyst, Dr. Lee Hunt, from High Point, N.C., police department, will be giving a lecture, Monday, Oct. 5, 2009.Â

Hunt's lecture, titled: "Reducing Violent Crime Associated with Overt Drug Markets: Focused Deterrence, Community Partnerships and Data Driven Policing," will be held in McComsey Auditorium at 7:30 p.m.Â It is free and open to the public.

The Violent Crime Initiative was first implemented in High Point, N.C., "to improve the quality of life for the residents of High Point by reducing violent crime, using a comprehensive, collaborative data-driven strategic approach-to identify violent, repeat and/or group offenders and employ prevention and intervention techniques to stop the violence," according to High Point Police Department's website.

Lancaster City, along with numerous other cities, has decided to replicate this program, which has won multiple national awards.Â The lecture will illustrate the elements that comprise the program, data analysis, results and how the program has been applied to other public safety concerns.Â
For more information, contact Mary H. Glazier at 717-872-3855 or 717-371-5663. Visit www.LancasterPSRI.org for more information on various reduction projects in Lancaster.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Autism I
event.shortdesc: Film: Rain Man (1988) -- Discussion led by Dr. Thomas Neuville, Associate Professor of Special Education, after the screening.

fulldesc.p: This event is sponsored by Common Reading , Office of the Dean H&SS, Compliments the Common Reading: "The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time."

Selfish hustler Charlie Babbitt (Tom Cruise) discovers his inheritance has been willed to a brother Raymond he never knew (Dustin Hoffman).Â Charlie kidnaps Raymond from his institutional existence and takes him on a road trip, where Raymond's autistic behaviors interfere with Charlie's greedy self-absorption. 1988 Academy Award Winner for Best Picture, Best Director (Barry Levinson), Best Original Screenplay, and Best Actor (Dustin Hoffman).
Free and open to the public.Â Post-screening discussion led by Dr. Thomas Neuville, Associate Professor of Special Education.

event.title: Musical Performance: Naturally 7
event.shortdesc: A group of seven musicians who practice something they call "Vocal Play”.

fulldesc.p: This event is $10 with MU ID, and $15 for community
This event is sponsored by the Millersville GospelÂ Choir, Footprints Praise Dance Ministry, Millersville NAACP, Office of Social Equity, Black Cultural Celebration andÂ BSU.

Naturally 7, comprised of Roger Thomas, Warren Thomas, Rod Eldridge, Jamal Reed, Dwight Stewart, Garfield Buckley and "Hops" Hutton, uses their outstanding harmonies to replicate instruments. Their stage presence has grasped their fans and allowed them to tour in Europe, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and the United States. Joining Coldplay and producer Brian Eno in the studio, Naturally 7 has taken music to a new level. Since originating in New York City in 1999, the band has release four albums, working to release their fifth in 2009.

event.title: Walk A Mile in Her Shoes
event.shortdesc: Join the protest against rape, sexual assault and gender violence by walking one mile in high heeled shoes throughout Millersville University.

fulldesc.p:
Men and women will gather to walk one mile in women's high-heeled shoes throughout Millersville University to protest rape, sexual assault and gender violence. The walk is being organized by the Elsie S. Shenk Wellness and Women's Program and the Millersville University Police Department. A portion of the proceeds from sponsored walkers will benefit Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster County.
The opening ceremonies and on-site registration are scheduled to begin at 5 p.m. with the walk beginning at 6 p.m. Men, women, and children are invited to participate and walk-on registrants are welcome. Men are encouraged (but not required) to walk in women's shoes and participants are being asked to obtain a minimum of $10 in sponsorships. We encourage participants to bring their own high heels; however, a limited number will be available at the event to those who do not have their own.
Registration and the start of the walk will take place outside of the Student Memorial Center, bookstore entrance.
Domestic Violence Services of Lancaster County, a program of the Community Action Program of Lancaster County, provides comprehensive services to victims of domestic violence. Services include: an emergency shelter, individual and group counseling, children's activities, education and outreach, a domestic violence legal clinic, and bridge housing. Business number: (717) 299-9677, website: www.dvslanc.org.
For additional information on the event, please visit: www.millersville.edu/wandw or contact: 872-3841 or womenscenter@millersville.edu. For additional information on the Walk A Mile in Her Shoes Program, visit: www.walkamileinhershoes.org.

link.name: Elsie S. Shenk Wellness and Women's Program

event.title: PBS Screening
event.shortdesc: There will be an advanced screening of PBS's Art: 21-Art in the 21st Century Series, Systems episode on campus.

fulldesc.p: Millersville will present an advanced screening of PBS's Art: 21-Art in the Twenty First Century Series, Systems episode on Oct. 7, 2009 at 7 p.m. at Myers Auditorium in McComsey Hall on campus.

Art:21-Art in the Twenty-First Century, the only prime time national television series focused exclusively on contemporary art, invites audiences to meet 14 of today's most accomplished artists as they create works that reflect important and timely global issues. The artists span five continents and include such legendary figures as Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman, John Baldessari, Carrie Mae Weems and William Kentridge. The screening, free and open to public, will be followed by a panel discussion with four Millersville University faculty members:

Gregory Seigworth, Professor, Communication & Theatre
Jill Craven, Associate Professor, Film Studies
Shauna L. Frischkorn, Associate Professor, Design and Fine Arts
Christine Fillipone, Assistant Professor, Design and Fine Arts
The panel will be moderated by Ty Clever, Director of Millersville University: South Central Partners.

This event is part of Art21 Access '09, a celebration of contemporary art and Season 5 of Art: 21-Art in the Twenty-First Century sponsored by Art21. Art21 Access 09 is held at over 300 museums, schools, libraries, art spaces and community centers and is organized in collaboration with Americans for the Arts' National Arts and Humanities Month. Visit art21.org for more information. The event is co-sponsored by Millersville University: South Central Partners, the Millersville University Department of Art and Design and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences. South Central Partners is a partner of the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts.

Systems, premiers Wednesday, October 28 at 10 p.m. (ET). This episode features four artists - John Baldessari, Kimsooja, Allan McCollum and Julie Mehretu.Â Systems focuses on artists who realize complex projects through acts of appropriation or accumulation, and sometimes create work so vast in scope as to almost elude comprehension. Artists invent new processes to convey the attitudes of today's supercharged, information-based society, examining why we find comfort in some systems while rebelling against others.
Â

event.shortdesc: John Jennings, associate professor of graphic design and chair of the graphic design program at the University of Illisnois at Urbana-Champaign, will lecture on visual literacy, popular culture, and the visual communication found in Hip Hop culture.

fulldesc.p: Please join Millersville University Student Chapter of AIGA (professional association for design) for an evening with John Jennings, an Associate Professor of Graphic Design and Chair of the Graphic Design program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Jennings frequently lectures on visual literacy, popular culture, and the visual communication found in Hip Hop culture. Jennings is also the co-author of the graphic novel The Hole: Consumer Culture and a co-founder of Eye Trauma, a web based collective of sequential artists, activists, and curators who seek to expand the public's perception of the comics medium.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Disney
event.shortdesc: Film: Mickey Mouse Monopoly: Disney, Childhood, and Corporate Power (2001)

p.strong: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Disney; Mickey Mouse Monopoly: Disney, Childhood, and Corporate Power (2001)

fulldesc.p: Mickey Mouse Monopoly explores how Disney films frame perceptions of the world.Â

em.strong: "A daring and disturbing look at Disney's power to shape mass culture. Anyone who cares about children and commercial culture should see it, but get ready for the urge to cover your eyes as Mickey Mouse Monopoly chips away at one of America's favorite icons and leaves you with nothing but the ugly truth."

fulldesc.p: Presentation and discussion by Dr. Chyng Sun, Master Teacher of Media Studies at McGhee Liberal Arts School of Continuing and Professional Studies (NYU) and producer and writer of the film. Free and open to the public.
Faculty facilitators include Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies, and Dr. Stacey Irwin, Assistant Professor of New Media.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Good and Evil
event.shortdesc: Film: Beyond Good and Evil: Children, Media & Violent Times (2003)

p.strong: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Good and Evil; Beyond Good and Evil: Children, Media & Violent Times (2003)

fulldesc.p: The simplistic framing of the dichotomy of good vs. evil has made a strong impact in American culture. Beyond Good and Evil examines the effects of this oversimplification on our children as it explores the political and media landscape in the post-9/11 world.

em.strong: "Beyond Good & Evil: Children, Media & Violent Times is a truthful and shocking look at how mass communication distorts and manipulates language and visual imagery. The video is a perfect tool in educating - for critical literacy-. Beyond Good & Evil graphically shows - how the media's overriding objective of satisfying an audience converts real issues surrounding race, war, and violence into nothing more than show business."

p.em: - Jeff Sapp | Writer, Teaching Tolerance Magazine

fulldesc.p: Presentation and discussion by Dr. Chyng Sun, Master Teacher of Media Studies at McGhee Liberal Arts School of Continuing and Professional Studies (NYU) and producer and writer of the film. Free and open to the public.

Faculty facilitators include Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies; Dr. Cheryl Desmond, Professor of Educational Foundations; and Dr. Tim Mahoney, Assistant Professor of Educational Foundations.
For More Information: See The Humanities Film Series Website or join us on the Humanities Film Series Facebook page.
Sponsor(s): The Millersville University Library, The Women's Film & Lecture Series, The MU CinÃ© Club, and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

event.title: Interactive Student Workshop: I Rhyme Like a Girl
event.shortdesc: Women and our relationship to Hip Hop. I Rhyme Like a Girl (IRLAG) is an effort to provide unnoticed emerging female hip-hop artist training and support through their activism and support.

fulldesc.p: I Rhyme LikeÂ a GirlÂ (IRLAG) is an effort to provide unnoticed emerging female hip-hop artist training and support through their activism and support. IRLAG provides artisitc development, performance opportunities, skills to become effective social-activists, and educational activities that will prepare artists to be at the head of a movement of female artists defining their own images. Toni Blackman will be appearing at this event.Â

Blackman is an international champion of hip-hop using rhythm, song, power, and her heart to stun audiences. She has been selected by the U.S. Department of State to work as the first ever hip-hop artist to work as an American Cultural Specialist.Â Having servedÂ in Senegal, Ghana, Botswana and Swaziland, Blackman has impacted lives across the globe.Â She has taken the stage with Mos Def, The Roots, Wu Tang Clan, Sarah McLachlan, Sheryl Crow and many more. Blackman is an activist of hip-hop and education throughout the world.

p.strong: No tickets are required for this event.

event.title: SPC Showcase Premier 2009
event.shortdesc: The Software Productization Center (SPC) is hosting their Showcase Premiere 2009, showcasing two Central Pennsylvania entrepreneurial businesses who received assistance developing their software-based businesses during the fall 2008 and spring 2009 semesters.

fulldesc.p:
Millersville's SPC will showcase two Central Pennsylvania entrepreneurial businesses who received assistance developing their software-based businesses during the fall 2008 and spring 2009 semesters: Cruzcourt, a virtual off-site cafeteria system with a web-based ordering system and Dynamics, a software company focused on providing applications that allow non-programmers to develop customized programs for business related purposes.
The SPC at Millersville University provides emerging technology for focused entrepreneurs within the Central Pennsylvania region assisting in advancing software products from concept to marketable product.
"So far, we are extremely satisfied. All the participating students have been dedicated to the project, easy to work with, and eager to learn. Also, we were impressed how all the students incorporated a lot of thought and organization before starting the project," said Adrian Fang, president and cofounder of Cruzcourt.

event.title: Step Afrika!
event.shortdesc: Step Afrika! is the only professional dance company in the world dedicated to the tradition of stepping.

fulldesc.p: Stepping, a unique dance tradition created by African American college students, usesÂ footsteps, claps and spoken wordÂ asÂ instruments to create complex rhythms and sounds.Â Step Afrika! has created a profession out of their dedication to the tradition of stepping. Based in Washington, D.C., Step Afrika! has represented the United States around the world performing in North and South America, Europe, Africa, Asia and the Caribbean. Step Afrika! has been featuredÂ in books, documentaries examining the tradition of stepping,Â CNN, BET, PBS and NPR. Promoting themes of teamwork, academic achievement and cross-cultural understanding, Step Afrika! has been a model for educational settings.
This event is free andÂ sponsored by the University Activites Board

event.title: Danielle Krcmar Exhibit
event.shortdesc: The Danielle Krcmar exhibit, "Only the Real" will run October 19 - November 19.

fulldesc.p: The Danielle Krcmar exhibit, "Only the Real" will run October 19 - November 19. Krcmar is known for her figurative sculptures using a secretÂ mixture of materials.Â Her work focuses on interpersonal relationships and pushing the realm of these relationships. She is currently an artist in residence at Babson college and resides in Massachusetts. Krcmar received her BFA in sculpture at SUNY Binghamton, and her MFA in sculpture from UMASS at Amherst.

Displaying exquisite scupltures, Krcmar's work has been reviewed in Sculpture Magazine, The Boston Globe, The Boston Herald, The Boston Phoenix, Arts Media, and The Rockland Journal. Her work has been displayed throughout New England and New York, including Fuller Art Museum, the Duxbury Art Complex Museum, the Gallery at Green Street.

fulldesc.p: The Millersville Community Parade is a university-community annual initiative started in 1997 by a group of volunteers dedicated to improving relationships between the Borough of Millersville, Millersville University , Manor Township and surrounding communities. Since then, the Millersville Community Parade has quickly evolved into one of Lancaster County 's largest and most dynamic parades. This year's theme is "Myths, Fables and Fairytales." Last year's march included nearly 150 entries and thousands of people. Everyone is invited to participate in the Millersville Community Parade. Participation is free for most entries and competition is optional.

event.shortdesc: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc.: The Legacy of Iota Sigma: From Pharaohs to Immortals.

fulldesc.p:
Library exhibit highlights Egyptian heritage trailing the evolution of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., founded on Dec. 4, 1906 by seven visionary men termed the Jewels of the fraternity at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. The establishment of the 414th House of Alpha occurred in 1975 at Millersville University (formerly Millersville State College) and has since then birthed sons of Alpha at Bloomsburg University, Shippensburg University, and Gettysburg College.
For more info. Contact AlphaPhiAlpha.IS@gmail.com
