event.title: Ghost Hunt and lecture
event.shortdesc: Learn about hauntings and paranormal events followed by a hands on investigation at Millersville.

fulldesc.p: Explore the unexplained and the freaky world of the beyond with Derek Bartlett!Â Learn about hauntings and paranormal events followed by a hands on investigation at Millersville we will be searching for ghosts!

Bartlett is the founder and president of Cape and Island Paranormal Research Society (CAIPRS)Â located in West Barnstable, Massachusetts. BartlettÂ heard about ghosts and legends of New England shipwrecks as a child and with a curious mind, decided he wanted to know the truth.Â In 2001 Bartlett formed CAIPRS, hoping to find answers to the legends of ghosts and spirits. Focusing his research on how and why paranormal events happen around us, Bartlett uses technical equipment and historical research in his case work. Bartlett does not try to discredit others work but instead is out to prove his own findings.
The Ghost Hunt and lecture is sponsored by Ville After Dark.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Gender
event.shortdesc: Film: Hedwig and the Angry Inch. RATED R

fulldesc.p: John Cameron Mitchell's 2001 rock odyssey stars the director as a transsexual rocker with a botched sex change that leaves her with an "angry inch.â Through artfully staged performances and flashbacks to Hedwig's childhood in East Berlin, the film raises questions about the construction of gender, sexuality, and the origins of love.Â Mitchell's directorial debut won wide notice and awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, the National Board of Review, and the Sundance Film Festival.

Late night screening.Â Free and open to the public. Introduction by Dr. Greg Seigworth, Professor of Communication Studies. Sponsored by the MU CinÃ© Club (Film Club) and the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.

event.title: Reframing Silent Cinema I
event.shortdesc: Special guest, David Shepard, will screen and discuss his restoration of one of Pudvokins 1928 films.

fulldesc.p:
Special Guest, David Shepard, Academy of Motion Picture arts and Sciences Visiting Artist. Special support provided by the Academy of Motion Picture arts and Sciences.
Film historian and preservationist David Shepard screens and discusses his restoration of Pudovkin's 1928 film about a Mongol herdsman believed to be the descendant of Genghis Khan. A masterpiece of the Soviet silent era and its montage style, this film is a must-see for film buffs.
For more information contact the SMC Ticket Window at 717-872-3811.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Silent Film Festival
event.shortdesc: Reframing Silent Cinema Storm Over Asia (1928)

fulldesc.p: Free and open to the public.
Special Guest, David Shepard, Academy of Motion Picture arts and Sciences Visiting Artist. Special support provided by the Academy of Motion Picture arts and Sciences.

Film historian and preservationist David Shepard screens and discusses his restoration of Pudovkin's 1928 film about a Mongol herdsman believed to be the descendant of Genghis Khan. A masterpiece of the Soviet silent era and its montage style, this film is a must-see for film buffs.

"This beautifully constructed and photographed revolutionary melodrama has been justifiable described as an 'epic poem' by many critics. Pudovkin's films, which include Mother and The End Of St Petersburg, place him alongside Eisenstein, Vertov and Dovzhenko in the forefront of Soviet filmmaking. -The power of the drama is enhanced by the use of visual metaphors, superb editing and the stunning landscape. This version is complemented by Timothy Brock's original score, performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.
Eureka Classics

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Silent Cinema II- Unseen Cinema: Rare Cinema Shorts
event.shortdesc: Film historian and preservationist David Shepard screens and discusses rare shorts

fulldesc.p: Film historian and preservationist David Shepard screens and discusses rare shorts, including some from his award-winning anthologies Georges Melies: First Wizard of Cinema, 1896-1913 (Best Series or Box Set DVD of 2007-2008, the jury at Il Cinema Ritrovato) and Unseen Cinema: American Avant-Garde Films 1984-1941 (the Heritage Award from the National Society of Film Critics).
For More Information: See The Humanities Film Series Website or join us on the Humanities Film Series Facebook page.

event.location: All at Myers Auditorium, McComsey Hall

event.title: Reframing Silent Cinema III
event.shortdesc: Reframing Silent Cinema III: BUSTER KEATON: THE COMIC GENIUS OF THE GREAT STONE FACE

fulldesc.p:
One of greatest comic actors, Buster Keaton mastered physical comedy. His signature "stone face" captivated audiences as he navigated through unpredictable worlds. In this session, Shepard showcases selections from his The Art of Buster Keaton, which was "almost universally regarded as the best video release of 1995." (USA Today, 1996).
"The greatest of the silent clowns is Buster Keaton, not only because of what he did, but because of how he did it. Harold Lloyd made us laugh as much, Charlie Chaplin moved us more deeply, but no one had more courage than Buster. I define courage as Hemingway did: "Grace under pressure." In films that combined comedy with extraordinary physical risks, Buster Keaton played a brave spirit who took the universe on its own terms, and gave no quarter. - [I]n an extraordinary period from 1920 to 1929, he worked without interruption on a series of films that make him, arguably, the greatest actor-director in the history of the movies." --Roger Ebert
Free and open to the public. Sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences, with special support provided by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

event.title: Reframing Silent Cinema IV: THE CHAPLIN MUTUAL COMEDIES
event.shortdesc: Film historian and preservationist David Shepard presents selections from the Chaplin Mutual comedies.
event.fulldesc:
Film historian and preservationist David Shepard presents selections from the Chaplin Mutual comedies, with recorded orchestral scores composed by Carl Davis.
"The 12 two-reel comedies that Charlie Chaplin made for Mutual in 1916 and 1917 are among his greatest works, looking back to the slapstick tradition from which he came and forward to the social and psychological explorations of his more mature, if significantly less funny, later work.Â David Shepard's edition of the Mutual shorts, available in various formats over the years, has long been the gold standard for these often duplicated and mutilated films.â€
-- The New York Times, July 18, 2006
Free and open to the public. Sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences, with special support provided by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

event.title: Reframing Silent Cinema V: DESTINY
event.shortdesc: This 1921 Fritz Lang film was one of Alfred Hitchcock's favorites
event.fulldesc:
This 1921 Fritz Lang film was one of Alfred Hitchcock's favorites (Hitchcock worked in the German film industry during the 1920s). The film features a woman whose fiance has been stolen by Death and taken to a walled-in area in a German town. Death gives the woman three chances/lives to save her lover: one in Arabia, one in Italy, and one in China.Â Will she figure out a way to save her beloved?Â Recorded orchestral score by the Mont Alto Motion Picture Orchestra.
Free and open to the public. Sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences, with special support provided by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
For More Information: See The Humanities Film Series Website or join us on the Humanities Film Series at Millersville University Facebook page.

event.title: Biology Department Colloquium Series
event.shortdesc: Millersville's Biology Department Colloquium Series features Ruth Welliver's research regarding plum pox in Pennsylvania.
event.fulldesc:
"Plum Pox in Pennsylvania: What do you do when an "old" plant pest visits a new neighborhood?" by Ruth Welliver, Pennsylvania Dept. of Environmental Protection features this session of Millersville's Biology Colloquium Series.
The Biology Colloquium Series takes a closer look at various areas of biology, getting the most cutting edge information from researchers currently working in designated fields of study. Faculty, staff and students are encouraged to take a look into new discoveries and branches of research presented during this series. The series will feature ten scheduled researchers and speakers ending December 12.
This event is free, open to the public and sponsored by Millersville's biology department.

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Identity
event.shortdesc: Reframing Identity: I'm not there

fulldesc.p: This event is sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.title: Reframing Identity: I'm not there
event.shortdesc: I'm Not There explores the construction of identity in the public sphere.

fulldesc.p:
Todd Haynes' 2008 postmodern pastiche of Bob Dylan's fluctuating personae stars six actors (including Cate Blanchette, Christian Bale, Heath Ledger, and Richard Gere) as aspects of Dylan. Following in the intellectual tradition of Citizen Kane and Foucault, I'm Not There explores the construction of identity in the public sphere. Cate Blanchett was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. "A tour de force" (Manohla Gargis, The New York Times).
Introduction by Dr. Jill Craven, Associate Professor of Film Studies. Post-screening discussion led by Chris Dallis, English Graduate Student. Sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.
This event is free and open to the public.

event.shortdesc: Educational workshops by Andrew Garcia of Ohkay Owingeh/San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico.

fulldesc.p: Millersville University will host an educational workshop by Andrew Garcia of Ohkay Owingeh/San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico. The workshop is an educational and cultural awareness program in recognition of November as the Native American Month. The workshop is free and open to the public.

event.title: Tewa Dancers From the North
event.shortdesc: Tewa Dancers from the North will feature a traditional Native American dance troupe from the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo ("Place of the Strong People").

fulldesc.p:
Tewa Dancers from the North will feature a traditional Native American dance troupe from the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo ("Place of the Strong People") in northern New Mexico. Their dance, which is considered a prayer and a duty, is performed to help the seasons flow and bring harmony to the universe.
David Wolfe, who is an Ani Yunwiyah (Cherokee) historian and art instructor, will speak on "The Present State of Indigenous America." The event will also include Joseph Strider, a modern indigenous/alternative musician and Mother Earths Daughter's Drum.

The event is open to the public and part of the 2nd Annual First Nations Appreciation Celebration. Adults $8 suggested donation, children $5 suggested donation, and free admission with MU ID. The event is sponsored by Circle Legacy Center and Millersville University Department of Social Work. For more information please call Circle Legacy at 717-823-2079.

event.title: Got Game? Bring It!
event.shortdesc: Got Game? BRING IT! - Millersville University Library celebrates National Gaming Day with Wii, The Beatles: Rock Band, gaming tournaments, food, prizes and more!

fulldesc.p:
Got Game? Bring it! Millersville University Library celebrates National Gaming Day on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2009. Millersville University Library will be hosting its second gaming event "Got Game? BRING IT!" Open to Millersville students, faculty & staff. The event will feature a Wii, The Beatles: Rock Band tournament, Wii bowling, and open-play time.
The event will be held from 1:00-4:00 PM on the third floor of Ganser Library. Participants in the Wii The Beatles: Rock Band and bowling tournaments are required to pre-register on a first come, first serve basis online at: http://www.library.millersville.edu/gamenight/ .
The Rock Band tournament winner will earn the opportunity to post their high score to National Gaming Day website competing against other high scores nationwide. Two popular board games are additions to the event. Say Anything and Wits and Wagers will be available for open play or impromptu competitions. Tournament prizes will be awarded and refreshments will be available so come to participate or just cheer on your friends! Millersville will join hundreds of libraries throughout the country for the second annual celebration of National Gaming @ your library. National Gaming Day @ your library is a national initiative supported by the American Library Association.
For more information on National Gaming Day please visit http://ilovelibraries.org/gaming. Additionally, this event is a part of the Millersville University BORED Program. As a BORED event, students who attend this event can have their MU ID card swiped at the BORED information table and be entered to win great prizes based on the number of events they attend. More information about the BORED Program can be found at http://www.millersville.edu/sprogram/bored/index.php.
The gaming event will be hosted by Millersville University Library. Please check the Millersville University Library Facebook page (http://www.facebook.com/home.php#/pages/Millersville-PA/Millersville-University-Library/37366458921?ref=ts) for more details.
To host your event at the library or for other information, please contact Library Outreach at (717)872-3617 or Library.Outreach@Millersville.edu.

event.title: Humanities Film Series Reframing Autism IV
event.shortdesc: Film: Ben x (2007) -- Discussion led by students in Dr. Neuville's class after the screening.

fulldesc.p: Director Nic Balthazar presents the world of Ben, a teen with Asperger's Syndrome, who plays an online computer game to escape from the harsh reality of bullies who torment him.Â As the bullying escalates, Ben finds a dream girl within the game who helps him confront his tormentors. "Rarely has so much emotion and excitement been compressed into 90 minutes of screen time" (Denis Seguin, Screen Daily). Winner of the Grand Prix and Audience Award (Best Film) at the Montreal Film Festival. In Flemish with English Subtitles.
Discussion led by students in Dr. Neuville's class after the screening. Complements the common reading: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time.
For More Information: See The Humanities Film Series Website or join us on the Humanities Film Series Facebook page.

event.title: Fall Concert
event.shortdesc: The All-American Rejects, Taking Back Sunday and Anberlin will be performing during Millersville's Fall Concert.

fulldesc.p: Pucillo Gymnasium will be opening its doors to one of emo's poppiest bands on November 17, 2009 according to Rolling Stone magazine. The All-American Rejects and Taking Back Sunday with special guest Anberlin will be coming to Millersville, performing songs off their platinum records. Doors open at 6 p.m. and the concert will begin at 7 p.m.

The All-American Rejects and Taking Back Sunday have created songs reaching the top of the music charts. Both bands began their road to fame in 1999. Joining the All-American Rejects and Taking Back Sunday is Aberlin. Anberlin, beginning its musical career in Florida, has been making the charts with new music and tours across the nation.
The All-American Rejects and Taking Back Sunday have come to produce music favored by millions of fans.

Tickets are $15 with MU ID, $20 for the general public and $25 on the day of the show. Tickets are available at the TicketWindow in the Student Memorial Center or can be ordered online at www.muticketsonline.com.

The Biology Colloquium Series takes a closer look at various areas of biology, getting the most cutting edge information from researchers currently working in designated fields of study. event.title: Consuming Kids-A Film
event.shortdesc: Consuming Kids: The Commercialization of Childhood, is about the practices of a multi-billion dollar marketing machine that sells to kids.

fulldesc.p:
Consuming Kids throws desperately needed light on the practices of a relentless multi-billion dollar marketing machine that now sells kids and their parents everything from junk food and violent video games to bogus educational products and the family car. Drawing on the insights of health care professionals, children's advocates, and industry insiders, the film focuses on the explosive growth of child marketing in the wake of deregulation, showing how youth marketers have used the latest advances in psychology, anthropology and neuroscience to transform American children into one of the most powerful and profitable consumer demographics in the world. Consuming Kids pushes back against the wholesale commercialization of childhood, raising urgent questions about the ethics of children's marketing and its impact on the health and well-being of kids.
Facilitators include Dr. Stacey Irwin, Assistant Professor of New Media, Department of Communication and Theatre, and Lisa Jurgensen, RN, CNM, MSN. Sponsored by the Department of Communication and Theatre and The Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, www.commercialfreechildhood.org.

event.title: Farewell to Lyte Auditorium
event.shortdesc: "Farewell to Lyte Auditorium" hosted by the "Lyte's Out Crew" is a benefit concert with all proceeds going to Aaron's Acres.

fulldesc.p:
Farewell to Lyte Auditorium will be hosted by the "Lyte's Out Crew," a student-run nonprofit founded by the classical music business course at the university.
Performances will include the Celestial Brass, Violinists Brittany Peterson and Seth Kerner, Lyte's Out Jazz Combo, MU Trombone Ensemble, Flute Quartet and the MU Men's Choir, along with Keenan Metcalfe on marimba.
Starting in the spring, Lyte Auditorium will be doubled in size to become Millersville University's new Visual and Performing Arts Center.
"Farewell to Lyte Auditorium" involves more than 60 students and faculty from the Millersville University music department.
Tickets are available at the door with a $5 suggested donation, and tickets will be sold for a 50/50 raffle.
For more information, contact the Millersville University Music Department at 872-3357

event.title: Derek James - Singer/Songwriter
event.shortdesc: Singer/songwriter Derek James performs in Club de 'Ville.

fulldesc.p: There are few places New York City based singer/songwriter Derek James hasn't been. From his first live performance in Australia, he's paved his way from the streets of Southern France to the swanky bar of Manhattan's Trump Tower. His music encompasses his experiences, and his experiences have been anything but ordinary.

Stray, James' debut album was written in the basement of a family's home in the suburbs of New York, where he worked as a live-in nanny. As eclectic as the places he's lived are the jobs he's held to survive. You name it, he's probably done it James worked as an editor of bar mitzvahs and weddings videos, sold spa packages, and passed out bottled water at malls-to name a few. But he's worked his way up, both as a young man living in New York and an aspiring musician.

But aspire no more James was recently a finalist in the Williamsburg 2005 singer/songwriter competition. James has worked with talents Nir Z (John Mayer, Genesis) and Godfrey Diamond (Aerosmith, Lou Reed) and now makes his local rounds at NYC premiere venues such as Rockwood Music Hall, Pianos, and Rothko. With a consistently growing buzz and offers on the table, he's now able to prosper from his first love: music.
This event is free and open to the public.

Millersville University music professors Vera Volchansky, Keith Wiley and Daniel Heslink will conduct "Music of the Season" featuring Donald Grantham's composition, "Fantasy Variations", Peter Tchaikovsky's "Suite from The Nutcracker" and a combined piece in honor of American Veterans, along with other seasonal pieces.

event.title: Aaron Brooks/Paul Manlove Artists Exhibit
event.shortdesc: "Two Views: Landscape Paintings” -- Exhibit will run November 23 - December 18.

fulldesc.p: Aaron Brooks and Paul Manlove have been painting landscapes together for the last year. They chose unpopulated areas in the Susquehanna Valley such as rivers, streams, forest interiors, fields, and quarries. Their excursions were a shared experience in nature and art. While they painted they had lively discussions about other painters, art history and their own work. Both Brooks and Manlove paint with oil on canvas, but they have different working methods, artistic temperaments and art historical references. This show is a visual chronicle of these two individualistic painters finding common ground in the landscape. Seeing the paintings side by side, viewers will appreciate how two different artists interpret the same motif.

Aaron Brooks has an MFA from the University of Pennsylvania and a BFA from the University of Michigan. He is currently teaching painting and drawing at Elizabethtown College, Millersville University, and Harrisburg Area Community College. Paul Manlove has an MFA from Brooklyn College and a BA from Millersville University. He is teaching art at Penn State Harrisburg.

event.title: Disney College Program E-Presentation
event.shortdesc: Disney College Program E-Presentation. Come out to learn more!

fulldesc.p:
The Disney College Program at the Walt Disney World® Resort is a one-of-a-kind, Disney-designed combination of education and work experience. Disney College Program Cast Members have the opportunity to:
* Build transferable skills that include relationship building, problem solving, and written and verbal communication
Obtaining and embracing these skills will help make participants an asset to any employer they have in the future, and these skills also will be helpful in their personal development.
* Explore networking opportunities at the Walt Disney World Resort
Participants have numerous opportunities to meet Disney leaders, attend learning activities hosted by Disney executives and make the connections they want to learn more about the professional roles available at the Walt Disney World Resort.
* Tap into educational opportunities that offer new courses coupling academic theory and Walt Disney World management expertise
All participants have the opportunity to take courses and possibly earn college credit. These classes will provide additional insight into the leadership and management concepts that participants will be learning in the workplace.
* Earn real-world experience with a leader in the industry
The Walt Disney World Resort has an international reputation for excellent Guest service and training, in addition to its popularity as the number-one vacation destination in the world.
* Make friendships that cover the globe
Disney College Program Cast Members work with a diverse Cast and live with people from around the country and possibly the world.
* Enjoy the privileges of being a Walt Disney World Cast Member including theme park admission and discounts on resort accommodations, merchandise and more
Cast Members enjoy a wide variety of discounts at the Walt Disney World Resort and within the Central Florida community.
Please come to our E-Presentation Tuesday, December 1st at 7pm in Roddy 144 to learn more!

event.title: Humanities Film Series: Reframing Media & Truth
event.shortdesc: Film: Standard Operating Procedure -- Discussion led by Dr. Timothy Shea, Assistant Professor of English, and graduate students in Dr. Craven's Critical Theory class after the screening.

fulldesc.p: This film series is sponsored by the Office of the Dean of Humanities and Social Sciences.
This film series is free and open to the public.

Award-winning documentarian Errol Morris explores the media treatment of the Abu Ghraib photographs and their representation/construction of "truth.âÂ "Morris creates a meditation on the meaning and reception of imagesparticularly news imagesin our culture at largeâ (David Byrne, Talking Heads).Â "Harrowing and hauntingâ (Richard Corliss, Time Magazine). Jury Grand Prize, Berlin Film Festival.
Discussion led by Dr. Timothy Shea, Assistant Professor of English, and graduate students in Dr. Craven's Critical Theory class after the screening.
